title: What will be the global price of wheat in November 2021, according to the IMF?
preds: Took another detailed look. The IMF data references Kansas city, so looked at Kansas city, wheat prices for Nov after roughly ascertaining that Oct prices + appx basis = IMF prices for Oct. The appx cash basis was about $0.7/bu. For Nov, the avg seems to be around 820ish + cash basis would put it the max -1 bucket.

Now that this question is effectively closed I've had a look at the source data. FRED (linked above), takes us to the IMF (1), which uses the the Hard Red Winter Wheat Price, Kansas City, which is overseen by the Kansas City Board of Trade (2), which is owned by CME. I'm not putting the energy into deciphering the sport price, the link is below (3), but would genuinely love to know if anyone does know anything about this. So using the data from December's futures contracts (4);
In Oct price rose from ~740 to ~785
In Nov price peaked at ~885 before finishing the month ~825 If (assuming market movements balanced out monthly highs and lows),
Oct ave = 762.5, 
Nov ave = 805,
Oct FRED = 294.0, then Nov should be around $310, and I've been wrong for most of this question.  1. https://data.imf.org/?sk=471DDDF8-D8A7-499A-81BA-5B332C01F8B9&sId=1547558078595
2. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas_City_Board_of_Trade
3. https://www.cmegroup.com/market-data/kc-spot-hrw-wheat-daily-price.html
4. https://www.cmegroup.com/markets/agriculture/grains/kc-wheat.quotes.options.html#optionProductId=7295&overrideFuture=KEZ1

Right now the pricing is 300 and the trend is increasing upwards. With this, there is more of a chance for the price to be between 300 and 340, with a chance of being higher than 340. Although this is true, there is also a chance of the price dropping a little and going in between 260 and 300.

Again very late to the party, so I had a quick look at CBOT Dec Futures which I assume drive the Nov Monthly prices (at least partially). At the time of the writing, the settlement price in bushels was 8.25, so converting to MT, I get roughly $303/MT. Reading the commentary, it seems that prices came off in the last few days which means they have been high for a period- which in turn would keep the avg price for Nov above $300.

Spot price is trending downwards this week, looks likely to close in and around $300 IMO (1), contrasting forces of bumper crops, inflation/supply constraints, and uncertainty around impacts of omicron variant on everything suggests to be ticking over into box 4. But all of these things (even the presence of a new Covid Variant of Concern, to some extent), SHOULD be baked into the price already. Which makes it difficult to predict how the market will react to the factors.  Ultimately, given the FRED number "are period averages in nominal U.S. dollars." and the October value of 294 is significantly higher than the oct average from MI (1), I'll have to lean to $300 - $340 1. https://markets.businessinsider.com/commodities/wheat-price

Falling Russian exports, bad weather is Australia.
https://www.allaboutfeed.net/market/feed-statistics/wheat-price-hits-well-above-e-300/

Since it was $294/ton in Oct (https://www.imf.org/-/media/Files/Research/CommodityPrices/Monthly/Table3NOVEMBER.ashx), we are roughly 2% away from $300. Looking at other comments, I think we are not sure about the exact methodology behind IMF numbers, but can still check multiple sources (whichever ones we pick) to gain confidence that price increase (avg in Nov so far over avg in Oct) is most likely above 2%, more like 5% or more.
Last I heard ex US Wheat was at 301 and ex AU at 348. Though I don't know the freight status of those prices.

With only a few days of trading left in the month, the average so far at very approx $303 (probably more like $305), and current prices at ~$310 or possibly more, barring a complete disaster, I believe that bin 4 is assured. Again, note that October's number is out at the IMF, which is where FRED gets its data: $294.04/MT. Click on the link below and follow these steps:
1. Immediately above the graph, on the left side, click on the drop-down menu labeled "Commodity (All commodities and Energy)", and type in "wheat" and click on the search (magnifying glass) button (not the "Go" button). When wheat appears, click on it and then click on the "Go" button.
2. The units displayed are "Unit (Index)". Leave it like that for a moment to compare all commodities with wheat. Change the units to "US Dollars" to see wheat prices only.
https://data.imf.org/?sk=471DDDF8-D8A7-499A-81BA-5B332C01F8B9&sId=1547558078595

Continuing to trend up.
Don't think it could make 340 but 300 is looking very likely due to daily prices, trends and futures pricing

October's number is out at the IMF, which is where FRED gets its data: $294.04/MT. @GMR The data used to resolve this question come from the IMF (who get it from the USDA). Click on the link below and follow these steps:
1. Immediately above the graph, on the left side, click on the drop-down menu labeled "Commodity (All commodities and Energy)", and type in "wheat" and click on the search (magnifying glass) button (not the "Go" button). When wheat appears, click on it and then click on the "Go" button.
2. The units displayed are "Unit (Index)". Leave it like that for a moment to compare all commodities with wheat. Change the units to "US Dollars" to see wheat prices only.
https://data.imf.org/?sk=471DDDF8-D8A7-499A-81BA-5B332C01F8B9&sId=1547558078595 Also, again, my impression is that most people here are looking at the wrong data to make their forecasts, because it's not completely obvious what the right data are. I suspect many are looking at Chicago SRW wheat: https://www.barchart.com/futures/quotes/ZWY00/overview
That would explain why the crowd is so heavy on bin 3. But if you look at Chicago SRW prices over recent months, they are much lower than the FRED data used to resolve this question. KCBT (Kansas City) HRW wheat has tracked much more closely to the FRED data in recent months and is much higher. Also, the FRED data are supposed to be Kansas City No. 1 hard red winter wheat, ordinary protein; it's not the bid prices for that, but it does seem likely to be some form of KCBT HRW wheat data.
https://www.barchart.com/futures/quotes/KEY00/interactive-chart

Just repeating my current forecast here and noting 2 things. First, the data used to resolve this question come from the IMF (who get it from the USDA). It is useful to look at the chart directly at the IMF website, and that data will also likely be available slightly before the FRED publishes it (it is late this month). What is interesting to note is that wheat is going up nearly in lock step with all commodities tracked by the IMF in their data portal. And especially in that context, it does not seem likely to me that wheat will fall in the remainder of the forecast. Click on the link below and follow these steps:
1. Slide the left side of the time window all the way to the left to see all time.
2. Immediately above the graph, on the left side, click on the drop-down menu labeled "Commodity (All commodities and Energy)", and type in "wheat" and click on the search (magnifying glass) button (not the "Go" button). When wheat appears, click on it and then click on the "Go" button.
3. The units displayed are "Unit (Index)". Leave it like that for a moment to compare all commodities with wheat. Change the units to "US Dollars" to see wheat prices only.
https://data.imf.org/?sk=471DDDF8-D8A7-499A-81BA-5B332C01F8B9&sId=1547558078595 Second, again, my impression is that most people here are looking at Chicago SRW wheat: https://www.barchart.com/futures/quotes/ZWY00/overview
That would explain why the crowd is so heavy on bin 3. But if you look at Chicago SRW prices over recent months, they are much lower than the FRED data used to resolve this question. KCBT (Kansas City) HRW wheat has tracked much more closely to the FRED data in recent months and is much higher. Also, the FRED data is supposed to be Kansas City No. 1 hard red winter wheat, ordinary protein; it's not the bid prices for that, but it does seem likely to be some form of KCBT HRW wheat data.
https://www.barchart.com/futures/quotes/KEY00/interactive-chart

My estimate is that this first half of the month is sitting at an average of $301
There is a nice trend heading upwards as well as a positive futures market and other indicators that could push prices upwards. 
I am not willing to go higher yet but feel that this is the right direction IF I am following the right market...

Just repeating my forecast to make a prediction that October's FRED number will be somewhere in the very general ballpark of $288/MT. And if it is, if KCBT HRW wheat's cash price (KEY00) keeps going generally up, I'll continue to move my forecast on bin 4 upwards. My impression is that most people here are looking at Chicago SRW wheat: https://www.barchart.com/futures/quotes/ZWY00/overview
That would explain why the crowd is so heavy on bin 3. But if you look at Chicago SRW prices over recent months, they are much lower than the FRED data used to resolve this question. KCBT (Kansas City) HRW wheat has tracked much more closely to the FRED data in recent months and is much higher. Also, the FRED data is supposed to be Kansas City No. 1 hard red winter wheat, ordinary protein; it's not the bid prices for that, but it does seem likely to be some KCBT HRW wheat data.
https://www.barchart.com/futures/quotes/KEY00/interactive-chart
From discussion here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1350688 while keeping my prediction for bin 3 above crowd forecast
Expecting an upward trend but cannot be certain
Price is dipping down, so adjusting accordingly. I still expect the upward trend to continue.

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-11-02/wheat-prices-are-soaring-as-harvests-falter-and-stocks-shrink And now the Chinese government is officially asking people to stockpile stuff. I'm not sure how much of an effect this will have, but it might be something.
"A notice posted on the website of the Ministry of Commerce late on Monday urged local authorities to stabilise prices and families “to store a certain amount of daily necessities as needed to meet daily life and emergencies”."
"“As soon as this news came out, all the old people near me went crazy panic-buying in the supermarket,” wrote one user on Weibo."
"State media urged calm and Zhu Xiaoliang, a senior commerce ministry official, told the broadcaster CCTV “the supply of daily necessities is sufficient everywhere” but varying explanations were offered for the notice. Some said the commerce department often releases such warnings in the weeks before national holidays while the People’s Daily said the ministry had issued its instruction earlier this year because of natural disasters, the surge in vegetable prices and recent Covid cases. The Economic Daily, a state-backed newspaper, warned residents against having “too much of an overactive imagination” but also said the directive was linked to the outbreak and was to ensure people were prepared in the event of a lockdown."
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/nov/02/chinese-urged-to-stockpile-amid-ongoing-covid-outbreak

The FRED data for this question are from the IMF. Click on the "Primary Commodity Prices" link from the FRED page, and you get to an IMF page.
From the IMF page, click on the link labeled, "By commodity, in terms of US$, market prices 1/". That takes you to a file with data and information about the data. The data exactly match the FRED page. Here's the information about the wheat data: "U.S. No. 1 hard red winter, ordinary protein, Kansas City $/MT (USDA, Grain and Feed Market News, Washington, DC) 1/" with a footnote: "1/ Average of daily quotations."
The best source for this data I have found to be the High Plains Journal:
https://www.hpj.com/search/?l=25&s=start_time&sd=desc&f=html&t=article%2Cvideo%2Cyoutube%2Ccollection&app=editorial&nsa=eedition&q=Kansas+City+wheat+prices Now, if I go to the USDA here: https://www.ers.usda.gov/data-products/wheat-data/
I can download a file for "Wheat Data-Recent". If I look at lines 9 to 13 of Table 20, or lines 3 to 6 of Table 19, or lines 10 to 15 of Table 18, for No. 1 hard red winter wheat, ordinary protein, Kansas City, the monthly prices don't match the FRED data. The USDA Grain and Feed Market News is put out by the Agricultural Marketing Service. If you click through a couple links you get to the USDA Market News, which is its more modern incarnation:
https://mymarketnews.ams.usda.gov/
I thought this might be where our data might come from: https://mymarketnews.ams.usda.gov/viewReport/3223
Another link here: https://mymarketnews.ams.usda.gov/public_data?slug_id=3223
But I can't find anything that matches. I'm starting to think that the IMF data source listed for their table isn't their actual source. I'm not sure they're actually looking at KC No. 1 HRW wheat, ordinary protein. The FRED data is similar but not identical to what's in these reports: https://mymarketnews.ams.usda.gov/filerepo/reports?field_slug_id_value=2879&name=&field_slug_title_value=&field_published_date_value=&field_report_date_end_value=&field_api_market_types_target_id=All
It looks like it might be pretty close recently, if not earlier. Also, it only comes out every week, and the data the IMF uses is supposedly provided daily.
Averaging the values for the weeks that include all of October, I come out with a prediction of approximately $7.841/bu = ~$288/MT for October. Let's see how that goes. The Nov. 1 value is $8.1175/bu = $298.267/MT. I think bin 4 is likeliest. @GMR, I think I ended up writing this after your last forecast. Hopefully something here will eventually be helpful.

Wheat rally keeps prices up for start of Nov - not sure what data I should be following but do note @belikewater points on KCWheat
pretty much every indicator puts today at between 295 and 300 though. I am increasing my Outcome4, too little too late forecasting wise but lets see what happens

I'm going a bit out on a limb here because 1) I'm going against the crowd, and 2) I'm not completely sure what the data are, but as far as I can tell, KC No. 1 HRW ordinary protein cash prices were already in bin 4 in October.
Later update: I think the FRED price for October is likely to be ~$288/MT.

I'm confused. The IMF data used at the FRED website says it's "Wheat, No. 1 Hard Red Winter, ordinary protein, Kansas City, US$ per metric ton."
https://data.imf.org/?sk=471DDDF8-D8A7-499A-81BA-5B332C01F8B9&sId=1547558078595
(Choose "Wheat" as the commodity; type it in the dropdown menu.)
So I think we should be looking at KC HRW wheat prices. That's supposed to be the data here: https://www.barchart.com/futures/quotes/KEY00/interactive-chart
But that data doesn't seem to match the FRED data.
I did find this: https://www.hpj.com/markets/cash-bids-remain-mostly-mixed/article_6019b18e-31c2-11ec-9237-d7c5be7cbda1.html
"Kansas City wheat prices Oct. 19, spot, fob track, included: No. 1 hard red winter wheat, ordinary protein, $8.44 1/4 to $8.58 1/4, down 3/4 cent"
This suggests that October prices should already be spending time in bin 4.
What am I missing? Any help would be appreciated.

At this point, the price would have to fall hard and fast to end up in bin 2. The current price is just under $300/MT and climbing. It will likely end October at about $300/MT. Dec futures prices are also coming up towards current prices. Given the drops in wheat crop forecasts around the world, I suspect prices will continue to trend up throughout November.

Wheat continues to rally, I was too confident of it staying below 300 and then stopped watching the markets for a few weeks with strong growth - gonna cost me in brier score
https://markets.businessinsider.com/commodities/wheat-price

Have y'all seen what's happening to fertilizer prices? It's collateral damage of the energy crisis in China. Fertilizer producers in China are struggling to meet demand, and separately, urea production has been cut. Urea is a component of most fertilizers, including types used for wheat; urea is the most important source of nitrogen in commercially available fertilizers (and is used as fertilizer itself). I can't imagine urea and fertilizer prices won't have an impact on wheat prices.
https://twitter.com/JavierBlas/status/1453746602552737797
https://www.reuters.com/world/china/china-seeking-resolve-issues-caused-by-power-curbs-higher-raw-materials-prices-2021-09-24/
https://extension.umn.edu/nutrient-management/nitrogen
https://blog-crop-news.extension.umn.edu/2021/10/with-high-fertilizer-prices-should-you.html
If we skip the volatility, the forecast is headed to bin 4.
Realizing that I shouldn't weight bin 4 too strongly, as wheat prices haven't yet tipped into bin 4, although they might well soon.
Prices haven't been in bin 2 since July and are currently trending upward, close to $300. Dec futures are coming up, too. Watch and wait.
Prices starting to touch higher ground.
Adjusted based on observed mom changes in FRED database.
It's interesting that Dec futures are at $276/MT, but the current price is $284. Hence, increasing bin 3 and adjusting.

Yesterday, I thought the Sept value would be approx $268/MT (+/-4), and it's $269.74. Down $5.14/MT from Aug.
As I've said many times before, the volatility is very high, so it's hard to make a tight forecast. This YTD, out of 9 months so far, prices have swung by ~$10/MT 2 months, ~$20/MT one month, ~$30/MT another month, and ~$40/MT 2 months. For only 3 months in 2021 has the swing been substantially <$10/MT.
I still see the trend as being generally up. Based on Oct 1 through 16, I expect growth to be in the <$10/MT (+/-5) range for Oct. over Sept; I expect Oct's value to be ~$275 to $285/MT. From there, I'd expect about a 55% chance of staying in bin 3, with a greater chance of bin 4 than bin 2.

Latest annual average is 185 and it seems a good margin here is +/- 50. Overall throughout the years, it should be around 170 to 270 ish. That's my look at it. So it could fall into bin 1 or 2 or 3 most times. My bet is bin 2. Looking to move forecast in this direction.

Predicting approx $268/MT (+/-4) for Sept, to be released shortly. 
It's hard to picture the average price for Nov to be more than $300/MT at this point, but volatile swings do happen.
Putting more weight on the high side of bin 3 than the low side because I suspect the general upward trend may not be over. (The crowd sees it the other way.)
Overall, just spreading out my forecast more because of the volatility.
Shifting my forecast upwards, as I think the overall upward trend is continuing.
I hesitate to spread the forecast so differently between bins 2 and 3, but current and Dec futures prices are trending higher.

I should have lowered weight on bin 5 a while ago.
General trend is up, but volatility is high.

Dec futures currently pricing in $259.56/MT Monte Carlo estimate:

Aug value = 274.876. A gain of 31 pts in one month. 3 months to go.
The swings are so large relative to the bins that it's hard (for me, at least) to make a meaningful prediction. Futures prices seem to be moving up at the moment.

My day job has me with a toe in wheat, and shipping container accessibility at the moment. The Australian bumper crop is not looking as good as first thought and shipping containers are about 30% more expensive then July, with 6 month wait for supply.  While none of these are direct inputs to the global price of wheat, there's the feeling that both points are indicators of which direction the price will move - or I'm applying local bias to a global question.

"The wheat production forecast for 2021 was lowered since the previous report in July mostly on reduced yields due to dry conditions, particularly in Canada, the Russian Federation, and the US, and now falling slightly below the 2020 record level. " https://saskwheat.ca/wheat-market-outlook-and-prices "The lower global ending stocks forecast was partly due to lower production estimates for major US wheat competitors, Canada and Russia. The USDA forecast the 2021 Canadian crop at 24 million tonnes, down 7.5 million from the July projection. The Russian crop was forecast at 72.5 million tonnes, down 12.5 million tonnes from the July outlook. Those reductions more than offset an Australian crop that was forecast at 30 million tonnes, up 1.5 million tonnes from July."
"Some of the buyers are in sticker shock as far as where prices could go. We just have to figure out whether some countries’ revenues are down due to COVID in places such as North Africa, and how much wheat they can buy at these higher prices. " https://www.world-grain.com/articles/15745-us-wheat-prices-could-be-due-for-correction-analysts-warn

Forward contracts make $260 seem most likely.   https://www.ers.usda.gov/topics/farm-economy/commodity-outlook/ers-outlook-reports-and-data/
Global wheat production in 2021/22 is projected at 776.9 million metric tons (MT), down 15.5 
million this month. Russia and Canada lead the way with a combined downward revision of 
20.0 million MT. The United States also saw a decrease in production of 1.3 million MT to 46.2 
million. Despite the large reductions, global wheat production is still forecast at a record due to 
partially offsetting increases to Ukraine, Australia, and the European Union (EU).

Thinking more and more that >300 /MT (8.1647 /Bushel) and <220/MT (5.98 /Bushel) are equally unlikely (but slightly possible) events with a slight bias towards upward movement.  Currently sitting at ~272 /MT

The possibilities are starting to be constrained by time. I don't think it's likely that November's number will end up farther away from July's number (243.6) than plus or minus 42. Minimum in bin 1, max in bin 3, barring some disaster.
Are futures prices too high or not?

data points. In a surprise, what appeared to be very tough US sanctions on potash – Belarus’ big export cash cow – now appear to be toothless as while a total ban on doing business with the main production company Belaruskali was imposed it appears that the trading arm, Belarus Potash Company, that actually signs the contracts, was not included in the sanctions. That means in effect that it is still possible to buy Belarusian potash and not be punished, although of course a lot of international companies will cut ties with BPC in case Washington changes its mind.   Even so, potash prices have already soared to over $500 per tonne, more than doubling from earlier this year. This is reminiscent of the US sanctions on the Russian aluminium producer Rusal sending prices up by a third in just over a week and causing so much chaos on the metal markets that the US Treasury Department (USTD) was forced to withdraw the sanctions again before the end of the year. And Rusal has less than 10% of the aluminium market, whereas Belarus has 20% of the global potash market…   If the loophole reports are right then prices for potash will come down again, but there are a lot of European companies that rely on Belarus for potash, and foremost of those in Ukraine, which has been the big loser from the Belarusian sanctions. The Baltic states will also lose as most of the potash goes out through their ports earning them hundreds of millions of dollars a year.

Spring wheat futures  (Sept and Dec) have hit long term highs as weather in Europe, Russia, the US northern Plains and the Canadian Prairie added to concerns about global supply. Futures trading is sitting in outcome 4 so I increased that and also outcome 3. Many other commodity prices have been dropping but current wheat is still in outcome 3 territory and with futures so high I have had to change my probabilities a fair bit. I am guessing that demand wont change much unless corn prices change drastically and so the only driver of price change will be supply - based on weather (looking bad) and maybe a bit on fuel price for harvest (looking better than recently). What else drives these prices? I am not enjoying this forecast so it may be my last markets based forecast for a while.
We don't know other people's thought, even if they tell us.

Supply forecasts to be down by 5% for the year but sitting on big highs. Demand marginally down. Nice report here:
https://www.agweb.com/news/crops/crop-production/wheat-production-worries-headline-july-wasde-report-carries-corn-prices Staying reasonably even for now. I feel like this could easily lead to a bad score for me.

-Drought in US seems to be minimized by strong global output. 
-Not knowing much about wheat prices, seems like prices/volatility peak during summer harvesting periods.
The June price fell to $238.76703. Shifting weights to lower bins.

I took the past 2, 5, 10, and 20 years of 5 month rolling % gains and ran a Monte Carlo simulation to get the following results (https://github.com/jmflom/Superforecasting/tree/main/IMF%20Wheat) 2 Year Bin probabilities: [3.913, 43.286, 47.556, 5.203, 0.042]
5 Year Bin probabilities: [22.7, 45.069, 27.499, 4.537, 0.196]
10 Year Bin probabilities: [39.485, 40.643, 17.358, 2.407, 0.107]
20 Year Bin probabilities: [36.523, 33.383, 21.831, 7.055, 1.208] Updating my past by leaning towards the avg of these.

Cautiously slightly optimistic that June FRED data might slow a slight decrease. Or if not June, then July.
Hoping that predicted great harvests materialize at something close to expectations.
Still, the last time prices were <$220/MT was Dec 2020. Prices would need to turn around pretty quickly to make it <$220/MT. If June ends up with a decrease, I may increase the weight on bin 1.

The IMF publishes the average price of U.S. No. 1 hard red winter Wheat (ordinary protein) over each month. The Sep 21 future in this product is trading at 585 while the Dec 21 future trades at 597 (cents per bushel). We interpolate between these prices to infer the Nov price as 593, and take this to be representative of the average price over all days in November. Then we convert from cents per bushel to get $217.88 per metric ton. We made many approximations so our confidence intervals are wide for this estimate.

@jflom made me think about things more. Adding something to bin 1 and reducing bin 4. Waiting for FRED data for June.
Further info: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1304330
242.5084/MT is currently priced into Dec 2021 futures

Rethinking.

(Also, in case anyone finds it useful, here's a simple calculator to convert from prices per MT to prices per bushel: https://www.cmegroup.com/tools-information/ag-calculator.html )

Non-verifiable anecdote from my day job.  An Australian grain distributor is currently looking to construct ~1M ton of emergency storage capacity in anticipation of a bumper harvest, given Australian wheat export is ~21M ton, but the storage is not solely for wheat, there's a lot of moving parts to consider. A few things to sleep on; Is this a reflection of the global market?
If there is a bump in harvest yields, will inflation temper the expected drop in price?
Are general market factors more likely to drive the price in the medium term, or will geo-politics play a bigger factor, i.e. tariffs.
As @Aleysia notes, wheat futures are coming down. I think I have been underestimating bin 2. Still, I'm not as optimistic as the market.

Many forecasters have touched on how wheat harvests are looking in the major producing countries, so I won't comment on that here. The FRED data is currently only showing data up to May 2021, which happens to be when spot prices spiked and it's come down since:

The previous prices of wheat indicate that the price of wheat is most likely going to go up from the current level.

1) The megadrought in the western U.S. doesn't appear to overlap with where wheat is grown.
2) I don't think COVID has really had an effect on Punjab (India's dominant wheat growing region).
3) I think that with the U.S. reaching herd immunity, big pharma will quickly trade vaccines for Canadian and western European dollars.
4) I'm not even attempting to analyze Chinese figures (because they're probably fiction anyway).
5) I DO think we're going to have 10-20% food price inflation though, but that's because of diminution in the value of the dollar (not supply scarcity).

$278.45 as of June 8 Worlds largest producers are China and India which account for 1/3 of global production. Add Russia and it's basically half. China, the Eurozone and India are the largest consumers. China consumes more than it can produce domestically, India is basically self sustaining. https://www.fcc-fac.ca/en/knowledge/economics/2021-grains-oilseeds-pulses-outlook.html It sounds like China's buying and global inflation expectations have pushed the price up and it's likely to ease over the coming months. A 7% drop puts it close to $260 so it's most likely to fall above there. That said the USDA is expecting prices to increase. To pass $300 prices would need to come up 7-8%, which is still a healthy increase so the middle bin seems most likely. It seems corn prices could push wheat up further as well and China will be very influential in that so will have to keep and eye on it. If prices are outside the middle bin it seems most likely they'll move higher.
I shouldn't rule out bin 2, as prices are so volatile.

Just over 2/3 of all wheat is produced by China, India, Russia, the US, Canada, and Australia, in that order. China's crop is forecast to be good this year, and their imports are expected to drop a little, which will ease prices. India is expected to have a bumper crop and will likely increase exports. Russia is expected to decrease exports because of export restrictions and lower production forecasts. In the US, people have been forecasting a record year for exports, but there are some drought concerns in several states. Wheat exports are forecast to be down a bit, though, because of rising exports from other countries and uncompetitive prices. Canada's production is expected to fall for 2021-2022, as is Australia's. (Also, Australia is in the midst of its worst mouse plague in at least decades, and many farmers are having to burn their crops because of it. If you haven't seen anything about this yet, Google "mice Australia" for horror movies and pictures. It is beyond your worst nightmares.) Overall, the USDA estimates that global wheat production will go up for 2021-2022, and that the farm price of wheat will average $6.50/bu in 2021-2022, up from last year:
"Global production is raised to a record with larger crops in the European Union, Russia, Ukraine, and the United States. Global consumption is revised higher with more feed and residual use, while global stocks are revised higher, mostly reflecting additional supplies in the European Union and Russia. Imports are raised for Turkey, Brazil, and Bangladesh, more than offsetting a reduction for the European Union. Exports are raised for Ukraine and India. The U.S. season-average farm price remains at $6.50 per bushel."
https://apps.fas.usda.gov/psdonline/circulars/grain.pdf Also from the USDA:
"The global wheat outlook for 2021/22 is for larger supplies, higher consumption, increased trade, and higher stocks."
https://www.usda.gov/oce/commodity/wasde/wasde0621.pdf
Other organizations are still predicting lower stocks, though. May price $278, and rising since late 2019. A general trend I see is to predict that wheat prices will be ~25% higher in 2021-2022, which seems reasonable. Fundamentally global wheat is robust, but it being pushed higher with the rising basket of commodities that are structurally weak/bullish. The latest June WASDE report projects 2021/22 season-average farm price unchanged at $6.50 per bushel. Dollar weakness, supply chain constraints, elevated freight costs should keep wheat range bound.
